title: 103_s1952
content:
The United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995 is cited in Section 1. Section 2 outlines the specifications of the coin. The Secretary of the Treasury shall issue not more than 500,000 $1 silver coins, weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.5 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins issued under this Act shall feature a rose, the national floral emblem, and a frontal view of the French facade of the United States Botanic Garden. Each coin will have a designated value, the year 1995 inscribed, and the words "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The coins issued under this Act shall be legal tender as provided in section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary shall obtain silver for the coins minted under this Act only from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. Selection of design for the coins. The design for the coins authorized by this Act shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design shall also be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The issuance of SEC-5 coins. Quality of coins minted under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Mint Facility - No more than 1 facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular quality of the coins minted under this Act. Period of Issuance - The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act during the period beginning on January 1, 1995, and ending on. The coins minted under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with a limit of 1 facility for striking each quality. The Secretary may issue these coins from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995. The SEC. 6 Sale of coins. The coins authorized under this Act shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, plus the surcharge provided in subsection (d) with respect to such coins, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales shall be conducted by the Secretary. Bulk sales will be available at a reasonable discount. Prepaid orders for authorized coins will be accepted before issuance at a discount. All sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. General waiver of procurement regulations. The provision of law governing procurement or public contracts does not apply to the procurement of goods or services necessary for carrying out the provisions of this Act. Nothing in this section shall relieve any person entering into a contract under the authority of this Act from complying with any law relating to equal employment opportunity. Distribution of surcharges is covered in Section 8. Distribution of surcharges received by the Secretary from the sale of coins issued under this Act shall be promptly paid by the Secretary to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. Audits are also covered in Section 9. The Comptroller General has the right to examine the books, records, documents, and other data of the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden related to expenditures. This Act is titled the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" and specifies coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue up to 500,000 $1 silver coins with specific weight, diameter, and composition. The design of the coins includes a rose and the United States Botanic Garden facade, with inscriptions of the coin value and year "1995". The $1 silver coins minted under this Act in 1995 feature inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". These coins are legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at one designated Mint facility from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins authorized under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be available at a discount, prepaid orders will be accepted, and all sales will include a $10 surcharge. All sales of the authorized coins will include a $10 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services needed for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will go to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. The Comptroller General of the United States can audit the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden's expenditures under section 8.
